properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Lake effect snow bands are expected to persist through the day. Travel may be impacted, particularly on Highway 17, due to low visibility in heavy snow at times. Conditions are forecast to improve later this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T02:12:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T10:13:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2788496733.2019
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected later today. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop late this afternoon and then persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible tonight with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. Snow squall warnings will likely be required later this morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T02:27:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T10:28:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1888836449.2019
Area: Bayfield Inlet - Dunchurch, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weakening lake effect snow squalls early this morning. Flurries and snow squalls are forecast to continue early this morning, but will continue to weaken with time. Local blowing snow causing reduced visibilities will continue be a concern early this morning. Local snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected by the time the snow squalls taper off this morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T00:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T09:47:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3286011555.2019
Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain over Nova Scotia will change to flurries this morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Total rainfall accumulations are expected to be quite variable, with forecast amounts ranging from 30 to 65 mm and locally higher amounts possible along parts of the Atlantic coast. Driving conditions may become difficult today as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T17:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T08:45:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3241164640.2019
Area: Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weakening lake effect snow squalls early this morning. Flurries and local snow squalls are forecast to continue early this morning, but will continue to weaken with time. Local blowing snow causing reduced visibilities will continue be a concern early this morning. Local snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected by the time the snow squalls taper off later this morning when the winds shift to the southwest. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Some of these flurries will then intensify into local snow squalls this afternoon and persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible tonight with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible this afternoon into tonight. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are forecast to begin near noon. These flurries and snow squalls are then expected to continue into Thursday morning. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible along with reduced visibility in heavy snow at times. A snow squall warning may be required today. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures have dropped below freezing for most of the Island as cold westerly winds move into the region. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries move in. A snow squall watch has been issued for eastern regions of the Island for this evening and overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today. Lake effect flurries are expected to develop this morning. Some of these flurries are then expected to intensify into local snow squalls near noon and continue through the rest of the day. Areas south and east of Elliot Lake are most likely to see the snow squalls. Local snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm will be possible by the time the snow squalls move east of the region this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls today. The squalls could start as early as this morning and are expected to continue through tonight. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible today, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible tonight into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. The local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T02:20:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T10:21:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4078571608.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Rigolet, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River. Time span: today. Remarks: The heaviest snowfall is expected this morning. Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-14T01:18:15-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible later this afternoon and tonight. Strong and cold westerly winds blowing over relatively warm Gulf of St. Lawrence waters will make conditions favourable for the development of snow squalls later this afternoon and tonight. Conditions will become unfavourable for snow squalls by Thursday morning as a ridge of high pressure moves over the Maritimes. Driving conditions will become hazardous due to snow, blowing snow, and high winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions will develop late this evening and intensify on Thursday. Wind gusts exceeding 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains will falling snow will produce near zero visibility in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate late Thursday night as winds subside to 30 to 50 km/h. ### Road closures are likely. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T04:43:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T12:44:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1623206742.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: up to 110 km/h tonight. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: today until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h today giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest tonight, with local gusts of 110 km/h expected, causing blizzard like conditions. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-14T06:54:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T14:55:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1075176600.2019
